story.iWant: to see the basic layout of my private dashboard, including placeholders for my bio, todo list, and the three habit columns ("Today", "Yesterday", "The Pile")
story.soThat: I have a clear structure for where my habits and todos will appear.

acceptanceCriteria.criterion: **Given** the application is running (`npm run dev`),
**Then** I see a visually distinct area for "Bio", "Todos", "Today", "Yesterday", and "The Pile".
**And** these areas are laid out according to the desktop design (two-row: "Today" and "Yesterday" side-by-side, full-width "The Pile" below).
**And** these areas are responsive for mobile (single-column, stacked layout).
**And** the layout uses placeholder content (e.g., "Your Bio Here", "Your Todos Here", "Today's Habits", etc.).

doc.title: Product Requirements Document
doc.snippet: The main user interface must display three primary columns for managing habits: "Today", "Yesterday", and "The Pile". On desktop, this will be a two-row layout... On mobile, this will be a single-column, stacked layout...

doc.title: Epic Technical Specification: Core Application Foundation & Habit Integration
doc.snippet: DashboardLayout (React Component): Renders the main two-row, three-column layout for the dashboard.

doc.title: Epic Breakdown
doc.snippet: As a user, I want to see the basic layout of my private dashboard, including placeholders for my bio, todo list, and the three habit columns ("Today", "Yesterday", "The Pile")...

doc.title: UX Design Specification
doc.snippet: Desktop Layout: A two-row layout. The top row will feature `Today` and `Yesterday` columns side-by-side. The bottom row will be a full-width `The Pile` column. Mobile Layout: A single-column, stacked layout.

artifact.reason: This is the entry point for the dashboard and the primary file to be modified to implement the new layout.
As per the story's dev notes, new generic layout components may be created here.

constraints.constraint: This story should only implement the layout with static placeholder content. No dynamic data or backend integration is required.
The layout must be responsive, adhering to the two-row desktop and single-column mobile designs specified in the UX documentation.
Styling should be implemented using Tailwind CSS, consistent with the project's architecture.

tests.standards: The project follows a "Lean MVP" testing strategy using Vitest for unit tests and Playwright for E2E tests. Visual regression testing is recommended for layout-heavy stories like this one.

ideas.idea: Create a Playwright E2E test that navigates to `/dashboard` and asserts that elements with test-ids for "bio", "todos", "today", "yesterday", and "the-pile" are all present.
Create a Playwright test that takes screenshots of the dashboard page at both desktop and mobile viewports. These can be used for visual regression testing.
A simple Vitest/RTL unit test could be written for the placeholder components to ensure they render the correct static text.
